choices: One OS per physical machine only
Multiple OSs to share one physical machine
explain: Virtualization decouples OSs from hardware so many guests can share one host.

q: A virtual machine (VM) is best described as:
choices: A full software emulation of a computer
explain: A VM is a software-defined computer running atop a hypervisor.

q: The software layer that creates and runs VMs is the:
explain: The hypervisor (VMM) allocates CPU, memory, storage, and devices to VMs.
Type 1 is installed on hardware for minimal overhead in servers.
ESXi, Hyper-V (bare-metal), and XenServer are Type 1 examples.

choices: Runs as an app on a host OS
explain: Type 2 runs within a conventional OS, common on desktops/laptops.
VirtualBox, VMware Fusion, Parallels, and UTM are hosted hypervisors.

choices: Always the same as the host
Any OS installed inside a VM
explain: Guest OS runs in the VM, independent of the host OS.

choices: Virtual processor allocated to a VM
explain: Hypervisors expose virtual CPUs mapped to physical cores/threads.

choices: On-demand IT services over the Internet
explain: Cloud provides compute, storage, and apps on demand via providers.

choices: Shift to operational expenses and elasticity
explain: You pay for usage (opex), scale quickly, and avoid upfront capex.
Data resides off-prem and traverses public networks; risks must be managed.
Provider manages hardware; you manage OS up through the stack.
PaaS supplies managed OS, runtimes, and DBs for developers.
SaaS is finished software delivered over the internet.

choices: Owned/operated by provider for many tenants
Owned for one org with maximum control
explain: Private cloud serves a single org, with greater control and responsibility.
Public clouds share pooled resources among many customers.

choices: Mix of private and public cloud
explain: Hybrid bridges private resources with one or more public clouds.

choices: Shared by orgs with common needs
explain: Community clouds serve groups like universities or agencies with shared goals.

q: NIST: On-Demand Self-Service means users can:
explain: Users provision compute/storage without human interaction.
Providers dynamically allocate pooled resources to consumers.

q: NIST: Rapid Elasticity implies capacity appears:
explain: Resources scale out/in quickly and often automatically.

choices: Metered usage with monitoring and reporting
explain: Usage is tracked for transparency and billing.

q: High availability 'five nines' equals max yearly downtime of:
explain: 99.999% ≈ 5.26 minutes per year.
PII uniquely identifies an individual (name, SSN, email, etc.).

q: AI differs from traditional programs by:
choices: Learning patterns from data and improving with feedback
explain: AI models learn from data and adapt via training loops.
ML covers supervised, reinforcement, and deep (neural) methods.
NLP powers chat, translation, and text processing.

choices: New text, images, music, and code
explain: GenAI creates novel content based on learned patterns.
Predictive models forecast outcomes like purchases or churn.
Chatbots handle scoped tasks; assistants handle broad tasks.

q: Cloud enables AI mainly by providing:
choices: On-demand compute and storage for training/deploy
explain: Cloud supplies scalable GPUs/CPUs and storage to train and serve models.

choices: Model performance degrading after changes/data shift
explain: Drift occurs when performance declines; requires monitoring and retraining.

q: Which NIST characteristic means services are reachable via standard networks and clients?
explain: Broad network access allows use over networks by diverse clients (laptops, phones).

choices: Shared pooled resources among many customers
explain: Providers pool compute/storage across tenants with isolation controls.

q: File synchronization in cloud services ensures:
choices: Files stay consistent across devices and cloud
explain: Sync clients keep the latest version on all linked endpoints.

q: Vendor lock-in is a risk because:
choices: Migration between providers can be difficult
explain: APIs, services, and data formats can make moving costly and complex.

q: 99.9% availability allows about how much yearly downtime?
explain: Three nines ≈ 8.77 hours/year.

q: 99.99% availability allows about how much yearly downtime?
explain: Four nines ≈ 52.6 minutes/year.

q: Capex vs Opex in cloud: main financial shift is to:
explain: Cloud replaces upfront capex with usage-based opex.
Public providers pool resources across many tenants.

q: Which term refers to the virtual memory given to a VM?
explain: vRAM is the VM’s allocated memory.

choices: Virtual network interface for the VM
explain: vNIC connects the guest OS to virtual/physical networks.

choices: A file or files on the host that act as the VM’s disk
explain: VM disk images live as files on the host storage.
Natural Language Processing powers chat, translation, and text tasks.
CV extracts meaning from visual data.
Networks of neurons with weighted connections; deep nets have many layers.
Classic AI using rule bases for domain expertise.
Chatbots focus on scoped workflows; assistants handle wider tasks.
GenAI creates novel content across modalities.

choices: Source code produced by an AI model from prompts
explain: Models generate code snippets/functions per instructions.

choices: Providing scalable compute/storage for training and serving
explain: On-demand GPUs/TPUs and storage democratize AI workloads.

choices: Regular testing, curated data, and retraining
explain: Monitor benchmarks, clean data, and retrain as needed.

q: VMware Fusion on macOS is a
explain: Fusion runs as a hosted app on macOS (Type 2).

choices: Use AWS services locally without an AWS account
explain: LocalStack emulates AWS APIs on your machine.

q: Which command pulls the LocalStack Docker image?
explain: `docker pull` downloads the image.

q: To target LocalStack with AWS CLI, you add:
explain: The endpoint URL points AWS CLI to the local emulated service.

q: Create an S3 bucket in the lab using:
explain: `mb` makes a bucket; `cp` uploads; `ls` lists; `rm` removes.

q: Which CLI lists objects in the bucket?
explain: `ls` lists objects in S3 buckets.
